thread.title: Mexican Ports Survive Biggest Ever Hurricane
thread.title_full: Mexican Ports Survive Biggest Ever Hurricane

title: Mexican Ports Survive Biggest Ever Hurricane
text:
Mexicoâ€™s major cargo port, the Port of Manzanillo , has reopened after luckily dodging the full extremity of Hurricane Patricia, which recently slammed into the country's Pacific coast, according to Reuters . 
At one point, Hurricane Patricia was the biggest storm ever recorded in the Western Hemisphere. 
Major preparations and even evacuations took place along the west coast of Mexico, but Patricia caused less damage than was previously foreseen, and port operations can therefore continue at an earlier stage than was previously thought. 
The Port of Lazaro Cardenas , south of where the hurricane impacted, resumed operations for cargo ships on October 24, 2015. 
A smaller port in Puerto Vallarta reopened on October 24 as well, according to the Mexican Communications and Transport Ministry ( SCT ). 
Despite being one of the biggest storms ever recorded, no fatalities have been announced. 
According to Coastal Planning Professor Dr Austin Becker at the University of Rhode Island and Oceanographer John Englander: "Seaports have a special need to look ahead, assess their risks and begin adapting to climate change. 
"Scientists project that events such as Superstorm Sandy, Hurricane Katrina and Super Typhoon Haiyan could become more frequent as oceans warm. It is much more certain that global sea levels will rise every decade as glaciers and ice sheets continue to melt, possibly raising water levels by as much as two feet by 2050. 
"Major storms, extreme tides and sea level rise can all pile on top of each other, and planners must consider a worst-case scenario when sea levels are high and a major storm hits at extreme tide. Though tides recede in hours and storm surge recedes in days, sea level will not go down for centuries. 
"Like the proverbial tortoise that wins the race, rising seas will eventually have a much greater impact than the other two issues." 
You can read Dr Becker and Mr Englander's insight into preparing for superstorms at the foot of this page.
